channel.title: How many of you guys want to become programmers as a career option?
channel.description: I'm assuming most of the people don't really have a apprenticeship in their main dream job in life, but if you do.. I suppose posting it will be okay, if it's slightly related to the title. As for me; I'm currently doing tafe courses in programming, and would love a career one day in this field.

item.title: How many of you guys want to become programmers as a career option?

item.title: How many of you guys want to become programmers as a career option?
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:47, topic:399106”][quote author=justinxg27 link=topic=496242.msg3628831#msg3628831 date=1308042419]
I forget a lot of what I read in programming… Honestly… I read a whole 400 page book and will only remember like 50% of the book… but I won’t give up just because of that.
[/quote]
Don’t worry about it, no programmer memorizes everything, that is what docs are for. What you want to learn is how to program, some algorithms you need, how things work at high and low levels, and different types of programming languages (for different types, look at prolog, lisp, java, Haskell, C etc). Actual languages and syntax doesn’t matter at all, once you learn to think like a programmer, you can learn about any new or different language in no time.

Last time I checked starting salaries for computer scientists range from 80k-100k USD/yr; then again you all are talking about lower level software engineering and such.

That’s actually a lot compared to other jobs now.

That’s a lot compared to any job… EVER; CS makes more starting than most engineering degrees. Only things that will make more are bio-engineering and petrol-engineering.

I think starting salaries are closer to 50k-80k (especially now), it can certainly and very easily grow to 100k plus though if you get into a good job with the right company. That is one of the major reasons I switched majors from Mechanical Engineering to Computer Science though, with Mechanical Engineering your salary tops out at < $60k, if you can even find a job. There will always be computer science jobs though.[/quote]

i like how you mentioned Haskell

Read full topic
item.source: How many of you guys want to become programmers as a career option?

item.title: How many of you guys want to become programmers as a career option?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“The Wanderer, post:48, topic:399106”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=496242.msg3630868#msg3630868 date=1308196798]

I forget a lot of what I read in programming… Honestly… I read a whole 400 page book and will only remember like 50% of the book… but I won’t give up just because of that.

Don’t worry about it, no programmer memorizes everything, that is what docs are for. What you want to learn is how to program, some algorithms you need, how things work at high and low levels, and different types of programming languages (for different types, look at prolog, lisp, java, Haskell, C etc). Actual languages and syntax doesn’t matter at all, once you learn to think like a programmer, you can learn about any new or different language in no time.

Last time I checked starting salaries for computer scientists range from 80k-100k USD/yr; then again you all are talking about lower level software engineering and such.

That’s actually a lot compared to other jobs now.

That’s a lot compared to any job… EVER; CS makes more starting than most engineering degrees. Only things that will make more are bio-engineering and petrol-engineering.

I think starting salaries are closer to 50k-80k (especially now), it can certainly and very easily grow to 100k plus though if you get into a good job with the right company. That is one of the major reasons I switched majors from Mechanical Engineering to Computer Science though, with Mechanical Engineering your salary tops out at < $60k, if you can even find a job. There will always be computer science jobs though.
[/quote]
Just a question, what is the difference between a major in Computer Science and Computer Programming? Or does Computer Programming fall under Computer Science?[/quote]
Huge difference, one focuses on design structures and production whilst the other focuses on theory and efficiency.

Read full topic
item.source: How many of you guys want to become programmers as a career option?

item.title: How many of you guys want to become programmers as a career option?
item.dc:creator: @the_wanderer The Wanderer
item.description:
@the_wanderer wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:47, topic:399106”][quote author=justinxg27 link=topic=496242.msg3628831#msg3628831 date=1308042419]
I forget a lot of what I read in programming… Honestly… I read a whole 400 page book and will only remember like 50% of the book… but I won’t give up just because of that.
[/quote]
Don’t worry about it, no programmer memorizes everything, that is what docs are for. What you want to learn is how to program, some algorithms you need, how things work at high and low levels, and different types of programming languages (for different types, look at prolog, lisp, java, Haskell, C etc). Actual languages and syntax doesn’t matter at all, once you learn to think like a programmer, you can learn about any new or different language in no time.

Last time I checked starting salaries for computer scientists range from 80k-100k USD/yr; then again you all are talking about lower level software engineering and such.

That’s actually a lot compared to other jobs now.

That’s a lot compared to any job… EVER; CS makes more starting than most engineering degrees. Only things that will make more are bio-engineering and petrol-engineering.

I think starting salaries are closer to 50k-80k (especially now), it can certainly and very easily grow to 100k plus though if you get into a good job with the right company. That is one of the major reasons I switched majors from Mechanical Engineering to Computer Science though, with Mechanical Engineering your salary tops out at < $60k, if you can even find a job. There will always be computer science jobs though.[/quote]
Just a question, what is the difference between a major in Computer Science and Computer Programming? Or does Computer Programming fall under Computer Science?

item.source: How many of you guys want to become programmers as a career option?

item.title: How many of you guys want to become programmers as a career option?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

justinxg27:

I forget a lot of what I read in programming… Honestly… I read a whole 400 page book and will only remember like 50% of the book… but I won’t give up just because of that.

Don’t worry about it, no programmer memorizes everything, that is what docs are for. What you want to learn is how to program, some algorithms you need, how things work at high and low levels, and different types of programming languages (for different types, look at prolog, lisp, java, Haskell, C etc). Actual languages and syntax doesn’t matter at all, once you learn to think like a programmer, you can learn about any new or different language in no time.

[quote=“T4_, post:37, topic:399106”][quote author=ox random xi link=topic=496242.msg3630337#msg3630337 date=1308166584]

Last time I checked starting salaries for computer scientists range from 80k-100k USD/yr; then again you all are talking about lower level software engineering and such.

That’s actually a lot compared to other jobs now.
[/quote]
That’s a lot compared to any job… EVER; CS makes more starting than most engineering degrees. Only things that will make more are bio-engineering and petrol-engineering.[/quote]

I think starting salaries are closer to 50k-80k (especially now), it can certainly and very easily grow to 100k plus though if you get into a good job with the right company. That is one of the major reasons I switched majors from Mechanical Engineering to Computer Science though, with Mechanical Engineering your salary tops out at < $60k, if you can even find a job. There will always be computer science jobs though.

Read full topic
item.source: How many of you guys want to become programmers as a career option?

@Ix_Soulcist_xI wrote:

When I thought about that option, it stuck for a while. Then I started thinking about being a game programmer or something. Then the idea turned to being a computer programmer, but now I plan on joining the Marine Corp., I might after I get out and what not.

item.title: How many of you guys want to become programmers as a career option?
item.dc:creator: @the_wanderer The Wanderer
item.description:
@the_wanderer wrote:

[quote=“IlikeArrays, post:38, topic:399106”]All you have to do to make big cash is come up with something creative and then make it happen.

Make some beats and auto tune your voice and put it on itunes…
Edit a youtube video and if it gets popular sell t-shirts…
Make something stupid like twitter…

You don’t have to have a job to make money, yes it ensures a stable income but look at all the skiddies on the interwebs doing different things to make cash.[/quote]
also called an entrepreneur.

Computer programmers will be around for a long time seeing the way technology is going. Nearly everything is a program. Quite a secure job field.

Read full topic
item.source: How many of you guys want to become programmers as a career option?

item.title: How many of you guys want to become programmers as a career option?
item.dc:creator: @ox_random_xi ox random xi
item.description:
@ox_random_xi wrote:

[quote=“CoonHunter, post:34, topic:399106”][quote author=ox random xi link=topic=496242.msg3630154#msg3630154 date=1308156442]

Truth is programming is only really profitable if you do it illegally and hack creditcards (that’s a no no) or if you can get an army of people willing to blindly buy what ever you want for 3000% what you paid to make it (Mr Jobs you sneeky bastard) so for me its just something fun to do that makes a little money without too much work. Also I’m currently taking collage classes for a criminal justice degree (damn you criminal minds cast, you turned me into you) so its nice knowing how to take down your teachers computer system when you didn’t study. Along with that the voice in my head tells me to do it so yeah.

Not entirely. My friends dad does programming for the FAA, he builds/implants the OS that runs on the Air Traffic Control computers. He has a government contract and he makes big bucks plus the economy can’t destroy it because he has a contract.

Still, when that contact runs out in like 10 or 20 years it will be hard to get that much money again. Basic thing is the majority of coders don’t make that much.

He has his own company, and he’s been doing it for a while and the contract runs out in 30 years.
[/quote]
He didn’t say everybody anyways. Programming an air-traffic control OS is like making a pinch-weld on a space-shuttle for NASA. One thing wrong and disaster happens. Your dad will make great money, yes, while he is on the job. Yet, when it finishes, he may not be able to get the same income.[/quote]
Not my father, my close friends father.[quote=“CoonHunter, post:34, topic:399106”][quote author=ox random xi link=topic=496242.msg3630154#msg3630154 date=1308156442]

Truth is programming is only really profitable if you do it illegally and hack creditcards (that’s a no no) or if you can get an army of people willing to blindly buy what ever you want for 3000% what you paid to make it (Mr Jobs you sneeky bastard) so for me its just something fun to do that makes a little money without too much work. Also I’m currently taking collage classes for a criminal justice degree (damn you criminal minds cast, you turned me into you) so its nice knowing how to take down your teachers computer system when you didn’t study. Along with that the voice in my head tells me to do it so yeah.

Not entirely. My friends dad does programming for the FAA, he builds/implants the OS that runs on the Air Traffic Control computers. He has a government contract and he makes big bucks plus the economy can’t destroy it because he has a contract.

Still, when that contact runs out in like 10 or 20 years it will be hard to get that much money again. Basic thing is the majority of coders don’t make that much.

He has his own company, and he’s been doing it for a while and the contract runs out in 30 years.
[/quote]
He didn’t say everybody anyways. Programming an air-traffic control OS is like making a pinch-weld on a space-shuttle for NASA. One thing wrong and disaster happens. Your dad will make great money, yes, while he is on the job. Yet, when it finishes, he may not be able to get the same income.[/quote]
Not my father, my close friends father.

T4_:

Last time I checked starting salaries for computer scientists range from 80k-100k USD/yr; then again you all are talking about lower level software engineering and such.

That’s actually a lot compared to other jobs now.

Read full topic
item.source: How many of you guys want to become programmers as a career option?

item.title: How many of you guys want to become programmers as a career option?
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

[quote=“ox random xi, post:33, topic:399106”][quote author=Andrew Ferguson link=topic=496242.msg3630150#msg3630150 date=1308156135]

Truth is programming is only really profitable if you do it illegally and hack creditcards (that’s a no no) or if you can get an army of people willing to blindly buy what ever you want for 3000% what you paid to make it (Mr Jobs you sneeky bastard) so for me its just something fun to do that makes a little money without too much work. Also I’m currently taking collage classes for a criminal justice degree (damn you criminal minds cast, you turned me into you) so its nice knowing how to take down your teachers computer system when you didn’t study. Along with that the voice in my head tells me to do it so yeah.

Not entirely. My friends dad does programming for the FAA, he builds/implants the OS that runs on the Air Traffic Control computers. He has a government contract and he makes big bucks plus the economy can’t destroy it because he has a contract.

Still, when that contact runs out in like 10 or 20 years it will be hard to get that much money again. Basic thing is the majority of coders don’t make that much.
[/quote]
He has his own company, and he’s been doing it for a while and the contract runs out in 30 years.[/quote]
He didn’t say everybody anyways. Programming an air-traffic control OS is like making a pinch-weld on a space-shuttle for NASA. One thing wrong and disaster happens. Your dad will make great money, yes, while he is on the job. Yet, when it finishes, he may not be able to get the same income.

Read full topic
item.source: How many of you guys want to become programmers as a career option?

Not entirely. My friends dad does programming for the FAA, he builds/implants the OS that runs on the Air Traffic Control computers. He has a government contract and he makes big bucks plus the economy can’t destroy it because he has a contract.
[/quote]
Still, when that contact runs out in like 10 or 20 years it will be hard to get that much money again. Basic thing is the majority of coders don’t make that much.[/quote]
He has his own company, and he’s been doing it for a while and the contract runs out in 30 years.

item.title: How many of you guys want to become programmers as a career option?
item.dc:creator: @ollie123 Ollie123
item.description:
@ollie123 wrote:

[quote=“m.dog311, post:28, topic:399106”][quote author=ox random xi link=topic=496242.msg3629605#msg3629605 date=1308101945]

I’m starting college in fall for a computer software development degree, which is Java, C++, and some database administration/general IT stuff.

Game development companies want Python as a language, which is what I want to start studying.
[/quote]And which game development companies would these be?

I think Bungie was one of them.

Speaking of Bungie… Anyone else notice they’re hiring PS3 programmers now?[/quote]

Yeah they signed a publishing deal with Activision, they’re not tied down by Microsoft or Halo anymore.
